Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Exploring Radical Anions as Catalysts in Conjugated Polymer Synthesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program and the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Anne McNeil of the University of Michigan is developing new methods to prepare conjugated polymers. Polymers are long chain organic molecules that derive many of their properties from the entanglements and interactions between the chains. Polymers have become ubiquitous materials in our daily lives, impacting most industries, including agriculture and food, health and safety, as well as transportation. While most of these materials are insulating a subset, known as conjugated polymers, can conduct charge and have been used as active components in light-harvesting solar cells and light-emitting displays. Professor McNeil will study new chemistries to connect molecules together to form conjugated polymers. The market for conducting polymers is estimate to grow to $ 1.6 billion by 2017, so the impact of developing a this polymerization methodology is potentially significant. The broader impacts further involve training undergraduate and graduate students, mentoring undergraduate students from minority groups underrepresented in the chemical sciences, and disseminating research results broadly through presentations at conferences and publications in journals.

Chain-growth polymerization methods for synthesizing conjugated polymers remains limited to a narrow set of electron-rich monomers. In this project, Professor McNeil is studying radical anion catalysis to synthesize conjugated, electron deficient polymers in a chain-growth fashion. Model systems for the putative radical anion mechanism-based olgomerization of the subject compounds are being developed and studied with the goal of understanding and controlling the initiation and propagation chemistries. A combination of kinetic and mechanistic analyses using reactivity studies, EPR spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, are being applied to gain insights into the chemistries of these systems and then to convert this knowledge into polymerization methodology. These studies should make a significant impact on the field as donor/acceptor copolymers with specified compositions, sequences, lengths and dispersities will be accessible for the first time.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

Performance_Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan

POR.DRECONTENT:
While most polymers are colorless insulators, a subset of polymers can absorb/emit light as well as conduct charge. These ‘conductive plastics’ are known as conjugated polymers. These materials are comprised of repeating units containing alternating double/single or triple/single bonds. Conjugated polymers have the potential to revolutionize the electronics industry by providing light-weight, low-cost alternatives in applications such as batteries, supercapacitors, fuel cells, transistors, solar cells, and light-emitting diodes.

 

For decades, conjugated polymers have been prepared using a method where monomers were randomly coupled in solution. These approaches are ultimately limited because the polymer molecular weight (or mass) and the sequence of repeat units are difficult to control. This synthetic landscape changed dramatically in 2004, when a new method for synthesizing conjugated polymers was first reported. In this approach, monomers are added to an activated polymer chain end, which enables the researcher to control the polymer length and sequence. Several limitations have been documented: for example, there is a limited number of monomers which undergo this chain-growth polymerization and they are all largely electron-rich. This limitation has significantly hindered progress in this field because electron-deficient monomers are essential to access both n-doped and low band-gap materials. The central goal of this NSF grant was therefore to develop a completely different approach to making conjugated polymers with control over their length and sequence, especially for electron-deficient monomers. Our preliminary results (gained through the effort of this EAGER grant) on model systems suggest that our approach is completely viable. Our ongoing work is aimed at applying what we learned in the model systems towards accessing electron-deficient polymers with control over their length and sequence. The impact of the proposed activities on society, both within the scientific community and the general public, is substantial, given that conjugated polymers are widely used for many applications.

 

The most significant broader impacts of our work completed under this grant include the highly interdisciplinary training of three graduate students and one undergraduate student (50% male, 50% female; 50% from underrepresented groups) in organic synthesis, inorganic synthesis, polymer synthesis and characterization, electromediated reactions, kinetics, and spectroscopy. One of these students has moved on to a successful career in academia, while the others remain at Michigan. Our research group consists of students from diverse backgrounds and experiences, and all students are actively mentored and supported during their training period. The overall goal is to strengthen the recruitment and retention of these students in STEM disciplines and prepare them to be the leaders of tomorrow, able to excel in highly diverse and collaborative work environments.

 

 


Last Modified: 07/31/2018
Modified by: Anne J Mcneil
